answers: strong nuclear force [or strong interaction; prompt on nuclear force]
quark-gluon plasma [or QGP; accept quark matter, quark liquid, or quark soup; do not prompt on plasma or gluon alone]
parts: Name this interaction whose magnitude increases with distance at high energies due to confinement. This interaction is responsible for holding protons and neutrons in the nucleus.

Unlike in traditional matter, particles affected by the strong force will experience deconfinement when in one of these substances. Matter must exceed the Hagedorn temperature to form one of these substances.

One method for analyzing the strong interaction is with the screened Yukawa potential, which contains terms for both the radius and the mass of these particles. These particles are the lightest hadrons.

answers: Ulysses S. Grant and Robert Edward Lee [accept Hiram Ulysses Grant]
parts: Name this 1864 battle where John Sedgwick was killed, making him the highest-ranking Union death during the Civil War. Horatio Wright’s troops fought desperately at this battle’s “Bloody Angle”.
These two generals fought each other at Spotsylvania Courthouse. They met again at Appomattox Courthouse.
Grant and Lee both fought in this battle that began the Overland Campaign. This battle was named for taking place in a heavily wooded area.
Name this 1891 poetry collection which contains the poems “If You’ve Seen a Mount of Sea Foam” and “I Have a White Rose to Tend.”
Versos Sencillos is most notable for including a poem that became this patriotic song. It opens by mentioning a “sincere man” from “where the palm trees grow.”
Jose Marti wrote “Guantanamera,” a patriotic song from this Caribbean island country.
Name this German athlete, one of the greatest tennis players ever, who first reached #1 in 1987 after defeating Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert.

In 1988, Graf became the only tennis player to achieve the “Golden” type of this feat, which normally requires winning all four major championships in one calendar year. This two-word term can also be accomplished in golf.
After beating Graf in the finals of the 1993 Australian Open, this Yugoslavian player was stabbed during a match by an obsessive fan of Graf’s, sidelining her career for the next two years.
Name this type of service whose televised, local variety is often provided by affiliates of companies such as CBS, Fox, and ABC and which typically focus on crime and sports stories.

This controversial media conglomerate currently owns and operates news channels that reach 40% of American households. Mandatory programming for channels owned by this company include the Terrorism Alert Desk and several editorials by Michael Hyman.

In 2018, Sinclair attempted to buy this now-defunct media conglomerate before the FCC shot down their acquisition. This Chicago-based company previously owned newspapers such as the Los Angeles Times and Baltimore Sun, and was eventually purchased by Nexstar Media Group.

Mozart created the villainous Queen of the Night role from this opera for the soprano Josepha Hofer as a way of showing off her skillful coloratura and ability to sustain high F6 notes in arias like “Der Holle Rache”.

Sibyl Sanderson made her professional debut playing the title soprano of this opera by Jules Massenet. In this opera, the title Byzantine sorceress refuses the hand of Roland until he is able to win a tournament.

This operatic scene from Act 3 of Lucia di Lammermoor has historically been viewed as one of the most demanding for sopranos, which has prompted singers like Dame Joan Sutherland and Nellie Melba to appended cadenzas to end of its difficult aria Il dolce suono.

answers: 1999 Russian apartment bombings [prompt on apartment bombings by asking “Where?”]
parts: Name these events that were blamed on the “Liberation Army of Dagestan”. Alexander Litvinenko claimed the government was behind these events in a book subtitled Terror from Within.
The apartment bombings were used as an excuse by this current president of Russia to invade Chechnya.
Putin garnered criticism for his handling of a hostage crisis in this type of place in Beslan, during which gunfire from Russian FSB likely killed 186 hostages.

answers: All Quiet on the Western Front
Italo Calvino [the novel mentioned is Invisible Cities]
The Man Without Qualities [by Robert Musil]
parts: Paul Bäumer (“BOY-muhr”) asks “What use is it to him now that he was such a good mathematician in school?” after a soldier dies in this Erich Maria Remarque novel about the horrors of World War I.

This author’s collaborations with the Oulipo (“ooh-lee-PO”) group inspired him to use mathematics to sequence many of his works, including a novel where Marco Polo tells Kublai Khan about his trips to 55 of the title places.
During an existential crisis, the former mathematician Ulrich joins a committee that plans the celebration of Franz Josef I’s 70th birthday in this unfinished novel.

answers: electrochemical window [or EW; or solvent window or SW; anti-prompt “be less specific” on water window]
parts: Name this quantity that appears on the y-axis of plots produced in cyclic voltammetry experiments. More generally, this quantity equals the number of electrons passing through a detector over time.

Direct current is applied to drive a nonspontaneous chemical reaction in this process, which is commonly analyzed using cyclic voltammetry. When this process is applied to water, hydrogen and oxygen gases are produced.

This is one of the most important quantities when choosing a solvent for use in an electrochemical experiment, since it gives the voltage range in which the solvent will neither be oxidized nor reduced. This quantity equals the oxidation potential minus the reduction potential.

answers: Lady Gregory and William Butler Yeats
Ireland [or Eire or Republic of Ireland or Poblacht na hÉireann]
airman [or aviator; or pilot; accept “An Irish Airman Foresees His Death”]
parts: Name these two authors who collaborated on the play Cathleen ni Houlihan. One of these two authors’ On Baile’s Strand was performed alongside the other’s Spreading the News on the opening night of the Abbey Theatre.
Both William Butler Yeats and Lady Gregory are writers in the literary tradition of this nation.
Yeats was likely inspired by the death of Lady Gregory’s only son to write a poem titled for an “Irish” person of this profession who “Foresees His Death.”

answers: Kray Twins [Reginald “Reggie” Kray and Ronald “Ronnie” Kray]
homosexuality [accept sodomy, buggery; accept literally anything about being gay; an extra high-five if they say “being gay and doing crimes”]
parts: Name this non-Australian city where delinquent “neds” joined the infamous “razor gangs.”

Thompson once pulled up with a shotgun to a bar owned by these identical London gangsters after they threatened him, telling them “you’ll not forget me”. These twins gained fame both for their legitimate nightclub business and their racketeering.
Ronnie Kray was vilified by the London press for engaging in this practice after his affair with Lord Boothby was exposed. This practice was mostly decriminalized in the U.K. in 1967.

answers: asteroid/meteor impact [accept impact metamorphism or shock metamorphism; prompt on metamorphism or shock waves; do NOT accept or prompt on any answers mentioning volcanos or volcanic eruptions]
parts: Name this process that uniquely produces silicate minerals with planar deformation features.
Impact metamorphism can result in the creation of coesite and stishovite, two high-pressure polymorphs of this mineral with Mohs hardness of 7.

The Brazil pattern of this process, in which two crystal share lattice points and grow into one another, has been uniquely seen in types of quartz produced as a result of impact metamorphism. Carlsbad names a law of this process for orthoclase feldspars.
Name this property which is possessed by facts and is opposed to falsehood.

This logician and mathematician outlined the semantic theory of truth in his Logic, Semantics, Mathematics, which introduced his idea of Convention-T, or the idea that truth is a property held by statements.

Paul Benacerraf argued that Tarski's definition of truth was in line with this theory. This theory, which was espoused by Kurt Gödel, is a variant of mathematical realism, which holds that mathematical entities are abstract concepts that are unchanging and lack spatiotemporal properties.

answers: F-A-E [or any permutation of the letters A, E, and F; DO NOT accept or prompt on partial answers]
Natural horn or French horn  [DO NOT accept or prompt on “English horn”]
parts: Name these musical notes. A violin sonata titled after these musical notes was partially composed by Albert Dietrich and Robert Schumann and is based on Joseph Joachim’s personal motto of “free but lonely.”

The aforementioned Double Concerto and the Scherzo of the F-A-E sonata were composed by this German Romantic composer and frequent collaborator with Joseph Joachim, who along with Beethoven and Bach is one of the “Three B’s” of German composers.

Brahms wrote an unusual trio that is scored for violin, piano, and the “natural” variety of this brass instrument, which also features prominently in the final movement of his Brahms’s first symphony. A modern version of this instrument is the only brass instrument included in a standard wind quintet.

answers: Krishna [accept Krishna Janmashtami; accept Hare Krishna]
Bhagavata Purana [accept Bhagavatamahapuranam; accept Śrīmad Bhāgavatam; accept Srimad Bhagavata Mahapurana]
parts: Name this figure. A religious movement named for this figure was founded by Swami Prabhupada, and has followers who sing mantras named for this figure.

The story of Krishna, including Krishna Janmashtami, is found primarily in this Purana. This Purana details all the forms that Vishnu has assumed, and lists devotee’s who primarily venerated Vishnu and his separate avatars.
During Krishna Janmashtami, this activity is commonly performed during Rasa Lila. Variations of this activity like Bharatanatyam and Kuchipudi arose due to differences in choreography.

answers: buffalo [or The Last of the Buffalo; accept American bison]
Yellowstone National Park [accept Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone]
Oklahoma (The group of artists is the Kiowa Six; the museum is Oklahoma City’s art museum)
parts: Name these large mammals. A native American on horseback dramatically thrusts a spear at one of these animals in a painting by Albert Bierstadt.

Bierstadt’s fellow Rocky Mountain school artist, Thomas Moran, is likely best-known for a painting that depicts the “Grand Canyon of [this national park]”. Other paintings of this national park by Moran commissioned by the US Geologic Survey are said to have inspired President Grant to federally protect this national park.

The Fort Marion ledger artists heavily inspired Stephen Mopope, a member of a group of six artists from this state that bridged ledger art with the flat-style of Plains art. A museum in this state houses a 55-foot blown glass tower by Dale Chihuly dedicated to its founder Eleanor Blake Kirkpatrick.
Give the common name for drawing congressional districts for partisan benefit. It is named after the governor of Massachusetts who served from 1810-1812.

According to a report from the Brookings Institute, gerrymandering in the United States has contributed to this political process. This is the process by which partisan differences increase and increasingly extreme views are taken.

This economist has argued for the idea of "asymmetric polarization" where one political party takes stances farther from the political center than the other. This former Secretary of Labor also wrote the books Reason and Supercapitalism.

answers: 10.5 base pairs per turn [accept answers between 9.5bp and 11.5bp]
x-ray(s) [accept x-ray interferometry or x-ray crystallography]
parts: Please give your answer in number of base pairs. Within one base pair, what is the number of base pairs in one full turn of the helix for the B form of DNA at normal physiological conditions?
This alternative form of DNA has a bp per turn closer to 12bp. Unlike the A and B forms, this conformation uniquely has a left-handed helix and only one large groove analogous to the major groove.

One technique for identifying the form that a sample of DNA is in does so by mixing the sample with gold nanoparticles and probing it with interferometry in this region of the EM spectrum. A crystallographic technique in this region of the EM spectrum was used by Rosalind Franklin for her pioneering images of DNA.

answers: Qarmatian [or Karmatian or Karmathian or Qarmatī or Qarāmiṭah]
parts: Name this government, which faced a massive revolt of African slaves during the Zanj Rebellion.
The Abbasids established this city as their capital following the turmoil of the Anarchy of Samarra. This city was brutally sacked in 1258 by Hulagu Khan.

This group sacked Mecca in 930 and ransomed the Black Stone of the Ka’aba back to the Abbasids for an enormous amount. This Bahraini subsect of the Ismailis defiled the Zamzam Well by filling it with dead bodies.
Name this weekly magazine, known for its dry cartoons, that is based in the largest city in the U.S.
In 1947, The New Yorker published this short story by John Cheever about Irene Westcott, whose marriage deteriorates after she uses the title object to listen in on her neighbors’ conversations.

The New Yorker also published this 1942 story by James Thurber, in which Mr. Martin decides against killing Mrs. Barrows and instead tells her a fake plan to bomb their boss. Its title is now used as an idiom referring to having the upper hand in a situation.
